docs.snippet: Secretary of State Vance gave a concrete reply last week to those who wondered whether the Administration would limit its criticism of human-rights violations to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries and whether its policy was only one of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Vance gave a concrete reply last week to those who wondered whether the Administration would limit its criticism of human-rights violations to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries and whether its policy was only one of words. He told a Senate subcommittee that the United States would reduce its aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia, where serious and widespread violations of human rights have been well documented.
docs.abstract: ed backs Carter Adm's foreign aid reductions to Govt in light of nation's human rights violations

headline.main: Human Rights: Deeds as Well as Words

docs.snippet: ed lauds rept by Sec Vance that Carter Adm will cut aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia; questions however argument that strategic considerations bar similar action in regard to Philippines and S Korea
docs.abstract: ed lauds rept by Sec Vance that Carter Adm will cut aid to Argentina, Uruguay and Ethiopia; questions however argument that strategic considerations bar similar action in regard to Philippines and S Korea

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 In the last few days, President Carter has had a new grandson, donated blood to the Red Cross, and advocated a number of good but neglected causes, including marriage, courtesy, punctuality, clarity, brevity and the United Nations.

docs.snippet: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27 Human rights activists, after years of being ignored or disdained as cranks, are riding a wave of popularity because of President Carter's focus on the rights issue. They say the experience is at once exhilarating and...
docs.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 27 Human rights activists, after years of being ignored or disdained as cranks, are riding a wave of popularity because of President Carter's focus on the rights issue. They say the experience is at once exhilarating and unsettling.
docs.abstract: human rights groups, after yrs of being ignored or disdained, are riding wave of popularity because of Carter's focus on rights issue; some leaders comment; pors (M)

headline.main: Human Rights Groups Are Riding a Wave of Popularity

byline.original: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 Argentina's military Government said today that the Carter Administration was interfering in the internal affairs of this country by reducing military aid to show its concern for human rights.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 1 President Carter met with the outspoken Soviet dissident Vladimir K. Bukovsky at the White House today and told him that his Administration's commitment to human rights was "permanent" and that "I don't intend to be timid in my...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 1 President Carter met with the outspoken Soviet dissident Vladimir K. Bukovsky at the White House today and told him that his Administration's commitment to human rights was "permanent" and that "I don't intend to be timid in my public statements and positions."
docs.abstract: Carter, in White House meeting with Soviet dissident Vladimir K Bukovsky, reptdly stresses his commitment to human rights is 'permanent' and that he does not intend to be timid in public statements on it (M)

headline.main: Carter and Mondale See Bukovsky, a Soviet Dissident; Carter and Mondale See Bukovsky

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, March 2 State Department officials said today that the Carter Administration was undertaking a detailed review of the previously approved sale of $1.14 billion in new antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia to decide if the export would be...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 2 State Department officials said today that the Carter Administration was undertaking a detailed review of the previously approved sale of $1.14 billion in new antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia to decide if the export would be permitted.
docs.abstract: Richard A Ericson, deputy dir of State Dept's bur of pol-mil affairs, says Carter Adm revs planned sale by Raytheon Co of $1.14-billion in Hawk missiles, deal approved by Ford Adm; several Cong members, most prominently Repr Benjamin S Rosenthal, have asked Sec Vance to cancel sale (M)

headline.main: U.S. Reviews Missile Sale to Saudis

byline.original: By BERNARD GWERTZMAN Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Although April Fool's Day has long marked the unofficial start of the twomonth peak season of annual stockholder meetings, plans for this year's gatherings are already well under way. In giving an accounting of their stewardship to their "bosses" the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Although April Fool's Day has long marked the unofficial start of the twomonth peak season of annual stockholder meetings, plans for this year's gatherings are already well under way. In giving an accounting of their stewardship to their "bosses" the shareholders corporate managers will be facing increasingly difficult questions and proposals concerning social and moral as well as economic attitudes.

headline.main: ROUND-UP; As Meeting Season Nears, Issue-Minded Shareholders Regroup
